narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very comprehensive history of citizenship since the conception of America to 1960
This course was a great introduction to the legal history of American citizenship, and was also a refresher of American history more generally.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Brendan was an incredible instructor ! No comments!

The syllabus was strong, and I appreciated the approach of reading four or five different chapters/articles each week rather than one book, but some of the readings were, frankly, too dry for my taste. With such a broad course, it is bound to happen that not every reading will interest every student, but I think Prof. Shanahan should identify the pieces that elicited little to no response from the class and try to replace those with more engaging scholarship.
Strengths: great readings, really supportive and thoughtful Professor. Weaknesses: would have liked more formats of discussion to break up the flow of class a little more.

Strengths: incredibly well organized, tons of clear and detailed feedback, lots of resources to help you write your papers, secondary source readings very well chosen
Weakness: Basically none! maybe we could have read more primary sources for class discussions

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Shanahan made sure that the class was really accessible for everyone dealing with COVID in different ways. He made sure to make our health a priority for all of us.

All of the practices in this course geared towards virtual learning succeeded. This success was mostly due to the fact that the Professor is very kind and accessible, making the course feel more "in person"

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If the syllabus interests you, yes, I absolutely would recommend you shop the class. This course was exceptionally well-organized and Prof. Shanahan is very kind and passionate. As a History major who specializes in U.S. political history, I was surprised to find that a solid portion of the material was new to me. As a broad overview of citizenship policy and inclusion and exclusion in American history, the class offers valuable frameworks and new angles for thinking through U.S. social, political, and legal history. The readings were often enlightening but occasionally dull or redundant. The term paper is a great opportunity to apply the course themes to a single case study or historiographical issue that you're passionate about.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in citizenship history, and you want to take the opportunity to go in depth with some really interesting case studies and projects.
